sections.title: Variable vs. Fixed Expenses
sections.content: Fixed expenses occur regularly and are predictable (rent, car payment). Variable expenses fluctuate and are harder to predict (groceries, entertainment, utilities). Understanding this distinction helps you budget more effectively and avoid cash flow surprises.

points.title: Track Everything
points.description: Record all expenses for 2-3 months to identify patterns in variable spending.

points.title: Create Averages
points.description: Calculate average monthly spending for variable categories to inform your budget.

points.title: Build Buffers
points.description: Add 10-20% buffers to variable expense categories to account for fluctuations.

sections.title: Sinking Funds for Irregular Expenses
sections.content: For expenses that occur less frequently (insurance, holidays, car maintenance), divide the annual cost by 12 and save that amount monthly in a separate account.

sections.title: Seasonal Expense Planning
sections.content: Some expenses vary by season (higher utility bills in summer/winter, back-to-school costs). Review your spending patterns across the year and adjust your monthly budget accordingly. Use past years' data to predict future seasonal variations.

sections.title: Improve Variable Expense Management
steps: Review 3 months of expenses and categorize as fixed or variable
Calculate average monthly spending for each variable category
Set up sinking funds for irregular expenses
Add buffers to variable expense categories in your budget

sections.title: Use Technology for Tracking
sections.content: Expense tracking apps can automatically categorize transactions and help you identify spending patterns you might otherwise miss.
